description: Ah, yes. The Subaru Impreza WRX. My pride and joy. A car often associated with flat-brimmed hat-wearing, Monster Energy drink-chugging ne'er-do-wells. And while I fall into none of these categories, I love this car all the same. From adventuring through the dusty roads of Pymatuning, hauling a wedding band around Pittsburgh, or traveling from State College through a Valentine's Day blizzard, she has never let me down.

This is it. This is the new NSX we've all been waiting for, and it's a hybrid! Sporting a twin-tubocharged V6 with 3 electric motors, two up front and one in the rear, Honda's reincarnated super car can sprint to 60 MPH from a dead stop in a mere 3.1 seconds. However, it is quite different from its predecessor. The original NSX was small, lightweight, and rear-wheel drive while the newest rendition is much heavier with all-wheel drive. I have to say, I still prefer the first generation NSX.

An exercise in engineering, the Bugatti Veyron is not one of my favorite cars: it was born in a cold laboratory, a science experiment, and feels devoid of any soul. It's not particularly pleasing on the eyes either what with its uncanny resemblance to a jelly bean. That said, it's fast. Like, really fast. Implanted with an 8.0L quad-turbocharged W16, the result of Frankenstein-ing two twin-tubocharged V8s together, it was once the world's fastest production car. Huh, I guess jelly beans can fly.

Found in an oceanside carport, this International Harvester Scout 800 Sportop appears to be one of the few surviving cars of a no longer independent company. While time has taken its toll on the car, it still stands proudly as a reminder of times long passed.

The Ford GT: a supercar with a legendary nameplate. Built to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Ford Motor Company, the Ford GT borrows many design elements from the GT40, a car that famously swept the podium in the 1966 24 Hours of Le Mans endurance racing championship. A new generation of the Ford GT is currently in the works so we shall see how it stacks up to its predecessors.

The forbidden fruit of many Fast and Furious fans, this is a third generation R32 Nissan Skyline GT-R. Never sold in the United States during its production, this iconic sports car must be imported into America by would-be owners seeking the Japanese classic. Wielding a legendary twin-turbo straight-six, the Skyline GT-R is famous for dominating the Japanese race circuit, earning the nickname “Godzilla.” So next time you'e driving around and you hear the roar of a kaiju, don't be alarmed. It's probably just a GT-R.

The BMW Isetta is a microcar that can surprisingly fit two large humans. This quirky car has the steering wheel attached to the door…which opens from the front of the car. It also comes equipped with a one-cylinder engine that produces just 13 horsepower!

The precursor to the modern Ford pickup truck, this 1948 Ford F-1 sits tucked away from the sun's rays, afraid to spoil its paint any further. Encountered in a small fisherman's wharf, the truck almost appears to peek outside its shelter, curious to the state of the modern world.

Meep meep! That's what it would sound like if you honked the horn of this 1970 Plymouth Superbird. You thought the Subaru STI had a big wing? Well this homologated racecar has one large enough to park another car under it! You might have also recognized this car as “The King” in the Pixar film Cars.

Rosso corsa. A color synonymous with Italian-bred sports cars, particuarly Ferraris. This one is a grand tourer, a car that combines high performance with luxury and comfort. The F12 also has the distinction of being powered by a naturally-aspirated, high-revving V12. In a world where emissions and fuel economy are tightening, it's no small wonder that cars like this are still able to hang around.

This is a 2003 Saleen S7. A favorite supercar of my younger brother, this particular Saleen boasts a naturally-aspirated 7.0L V8 that can rocket the car to 60 miles per hour in 3.3 seconds and to 100 in 7.1 seconds! Personally signed by Steve Saleen, this supercar represents just 1 of the 40 naturally-aspirated versions ever produced.

Photo credit: Byron

You know, there was once a time where I didn't like this car. That time was when I was first introduced to it via Need for Speed: Most Wanted circa the year 2005. I thought it was silly and sounded whiny. Now, I think quite the opposite—now, it's a beautiful car with a glorious engine note, one that sings to 8,000 RPM, a rear-wheel drive supercar with a 5.7L V10 propelled by a 6-speed manual transmission. Now, I see it as a perfect car. Alas, it also has the tragic distinction of being the car Paul Walker passed away in, RIP. May your tuna always be on white with no crust.

The BRAT, standing for Bi-drive Recreational All-terrain Transporter, was a vehicle made from 1978-1993. It featured (suicidal) jumpseats in the bed that were used to circumvent the “Chicken tax” as it enabled the BRAT to be classified as a passenger vehicle as opposed to a light truck. President Ronald Reagan once owned one of these on his California ranch, although I choose to believe he rode in the front seats…

Yet another restricted Japanese car due to American laws. Thankfully, this one isn't a real Nissan S15 Silvia or it would be making an appointment with the crushers (who I hear can be quite oppressive). Despite the autombile import bans, conversions of older Silvias—which are legal in the US—are quite popular, as seen here.

This special edition Legacy is one of 286 ever produced and, per /r/Subaru, is the only one in North America. It features a 2.0L sequential twin-turbo flat-four mated to a 6-speed manual transmission. Like many other iconic, “taboo” Japanese cars, it is right-hand drive and must be imported into the United States.

One ride in the Ariel Atom will most likely break your face. This is essentially a street-legal go-kart that is so utterly ridiculous, it's a wonder how it ever made it past development to begin with. It doesn't have a windshield, weighs less than one-and-a-half tons, and has anywhere from 200 to 500 horsepower(!) depending on the version. I take back what I said earlier. You will definitely break your face. I recommend a helmet.

Big engine. Big power. Big price. Powered by a 7.0L V12 making over 800 horsepower, this 2.3 million dollar car is so brutal, it's illegal to drive it on the street. Yes, that's right. This monstrous supercar can only be driven on a track. Let's be honest though. You might crash it on the street if you so much as blip the throttle. Being 1 of 24 produced, a replacement seems unlikely.
